Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Virtual Training, Evaluation, and Tracking of Program Impact
Award.AbstractNarration:
The I-Corps rogram aims to increase the economic and societal impact of NSF research funding by enabling the commercialization of research and by equipping scientists and engineers with skills and experience in developing economically-scalable models for technology commercialization. Program participants focus on learning and using a structured process that enables them to gather input from users and potential customers to evaluate and define a translational path from fundamental research into applications that have commercial potential and societal benefit. Many I-Corps teams go on to form companies operating in a broad range of sectors including health, energy, materials, agriculture, and information technology. This structured, repeatable program engages a national community of institutions and faculty to deliver training that results in economic outcomes. Through the proposed work, VentureWell will support the training of more than 1500 additional individual I-Corps participants. The proposed effort will also generate additional I-Corps faculty to increase the diversity of the faculty pool, enhance the program pedagogy, and advance the systematic data collection and tracking of teams immediately before and long after formal participation in the program.

NSF established the I-Corps training program in 2011 to train NSF-funded researchers how to evaluate the commercial potential of their scientific research. VentureWell's evaluation of program outcomes and tracking of program impact in a systematic, timely way has been critical to the operation of a consistent, effective, high-fidelity program at scale, and to the measurement of long-term program results. The core intellectual merit of this work is the insight provided into the program's impact — both economic outcomes and participants' career and research outcomes — over time. To gain this insight, VentureWell evaluates the delivery of each cohort, administers a longitudinal outcomes survey, and tracks venture outcomes independently to verify program impact data. The processes and data systems that efficiently track outcomes and provide insights into the development of technology-based ventures are a product of this work as well. VentureWell will support the transformation of all training to have virtual offering options while curating and disseminating pedagogical learnings to enable further development of the national I-Corps faculty. VentureWell will continue to work within the National Innovation Network (NIN) to disseminate effective course practices, outcomes, and impact enabling the NIN to effectively adopt and institutionalize these approaches. This support will further NSF's goal of advancing this high-impact program providing leadership in the national innovation ecosystem through NSF I-Corps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NATIONAL COLLEGIATE INVENTORS & INNOVATORS ALLIANCE, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 2011, VentureWell has partnered with the National Science Foundation (NSF) to run the Innovation Corps (I-Corps) program, which offers intensive lean startup training to academic researchers and students. This initiative directs NSF funds for basic research toward practical applications that benefit society. The I-Corps program teaches participants to evaluate the commercial viability of their innovations and develop a business model through customer discovery. Its ultimate goal is to accelerate the commercialization of NSF-funded research to foster new business opportunities, enhance manufacturing, increase national economic vitality, and translate scientific and technological research into societal benefits. Thirteen years on, the I-Corps program has enhanced the economic and societal benefits of NSF research funding directly, by commercializing research, and indirectly, by equipping scientists and engineers with the skills to develop and test scalable economic models for products and technologies. As of December 2023, over 2,991 I-Corps teams—representing 9,940 individuals—have completed rigorous training in business model development and customer validation. These teams have launched more than 1,614 startups, with over $4.43 billion in total funding.

VentureWell has supported NSF’s program goals in key areas including course delivery, instructor training, diversification and expansion of the instructor pool, knowledge sharing, course evaluation, collection of data on course outcomes, regional data collection, and dissemination of program information. 

VentureWell has supported the implementation of academic cohorts, SBIR Beat-the-Odds Bootcamp cohorts, and All-SBIR cohorts. This involved contracting faculty and teaching assistants, managing virtual sessions, conducting course evaluations, and identifying pedagogical best practices. Additionally, VentureWell monitored ongoing team progress, administering longitudinal surveys, collecting and verifying self-reported team metrics, and analyzing data at both individual and team levels.

VentureWell implemented and currently manages a user-centered Course Management Software in partnership with the NSF to meet the needs of entirely virtual cohorts. A team-centric Learning Management System providing a single user-centered space houses all course documentation, assignments, and cohort-specific data, thereby improving the virtual delivery of the I-Corps program. Additionally, VentureWell implemented a software tool for Business Model Canvas and Interview Tracking and this has served over 1,000 users across 15 cohorts since its inception.

VentureWell has continued working on extending third-party data integrations to include USA Spending data to add further value to the process for validating course outcomes. The process encompassed research of third-party data sources, design of data integration processes, and quality assurance tests. The USA Spending pipeline was put in place in Fall 2023 and has documented an additional $151M in follow-on funding obtained by NSF I-Corps teams to the VentureWell database. 

American Innovation and Competitiveness Act (AICA) reporting requirements were fulfilled by preparing and sharing data with NSF that included participant demographics, program outputs, and economic outcomes. Additionally, VentureWell continues to maintain and distribute a public-use dataset by integrating survey data from the NSF I-Corps National Program. The current 4.0 version of the public-use dataset was released in 2023 and contains over 75 cohorts spanning more than 7 years, with over 4,900 anonymized records. As of December 31, 2023, it has been accessed by more than 80 discrete users.

VentureWell has supported NSF in collecting and reporting regional I-Corps data. VentureWell maintains a custom-built data collection portal for I-Corps Hubs, enabling Hubs to share event and participant information and access data collected by VentureWell. Currently, 10 I-Corps Hubs actively use this portal. To additionally support the hubs, VentureWell and the I-Corps South Node collaborated to create the I-Corps Hub Academy, which provided 11 aspiring national I-Corps instructors training. Following the I-Corps Hub Academy, 4 participants were immediately placed in summer 2023 cohorts as lead instructors. In Fall 2023, three I-Corps Hub Academy participants were appointed as adjunct instructors for the Fall cohorts.

VentureWell undertook several initiatives, at NSF’s request, to better understand and support participants’ experience of the course in its current, online format. To support learners, VentureWell deployed a new I-Corps video library centered on the Lean Startup method. Current I-Corps instructors were contracted to participate in the videos and provide content. All 34 videos in the new I-Corps video library have been successfully woven into the existing curriculum within the LMS platform. Over 5 cohorts, with 444 users and 54 instructors, have accessed and viewed these videos. 

This award also supported VentureWell in taking steps towards evaluation and data system optimization for the I-Corps program. As the program grows, it is critical that program outcomes, pedagogy, and follow-on results are continuously evaluated in order to monitor and maintain the quality and consistency of the program. This award significantly contributed to VentureWell’s ongoing efforts towards these goals. 


Last Modified: 04/17/2024
Modified by: Philip J Weilerstein
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Since 2011, VentureWell has partnered with the National Science Foundation (NSF) to run the Innovation Corps (I-Corps) program, which offers intensive lean startup training to academic researchers and students. This initiative directs NSF funds for basic research toward practical applications that benefit society. The I-Corps program teaches participants to evaluate the commercial viability of their innovations and develop a business model through customer discovery. Its ultimate goal is to accelerate the commercialization of NSF-funded research to foster new business opportunities, enhance manufacturing, increase national economic vitality, and translate scientific and technological research into societal benefits. Thirteen years on, the I-Corps program has enhanced the economic and societal benefits of NSF research funding directly, by commercializing research, and indirectly, by equipping scientists and engineers with the skills to develop and test scalable economic models for products and technologies. As of December 2023, over 2,991 I-Corps teamsrepresenting 9,940 individualshave completed rigorous training in business model development and customer validation. These teams have launched more than 1,614 startups, with over $4.43 billion in total funding. VentureWell has supported NSFs program goals in key areas including course delivery, instructor training, diversification and expansion of the instructor pool, knowledge sharing, course evaluation, collection of data on course outcomes, regional data collection, and dissemination of program information. VentureWell has supported the implementation of academic cohorts, SBIR Beat-the-Odds Bootcamp cohorts, and All-SBIR cohorts. VentureWell has continued working on extending third-party data integrations to include USA Spending data to add further value to the process for validating course outcomes. The USA Spending pipeline was put in place in Fall 2023 and has documented an additional $151M in follow-on funding obtained by NSF I-Corps teams to the VentureWell database. American Innovation and Competitiveness Act (AICA) reporting requirements were fulfilled by preparing and sharing data with NSF that included participant demographics, program outputs, and economic outcomes. The current 4.0 version of the public-use dataset was released in 2023 and contains over 75 cohorts spanning more than 7 years, with over 4,900 anonymized records. VentureWell maintains a custom-built data collection portal for I-Corps Hubs, enabling Hubs to share event and participant information and access data collected by VentureWell. Currently, 10 I-Corps Hubs actively use this portal. To additionally support the hubs, VentureWell and the I-Corps South Node collaborated to create the I-Corps Hub Academy, which provided 11 aspiring national I-Corps instructors training. Following the I-Corps Hub Academy, 4 participants were immediately placed in summer 2023 cohorts as lead instructors. In Fall 2023, three I-Corps Hub Academy participants were appointed as adjunct instructors for the Fall cohorts. VentureWell undertook several initiatives, at NSFs request, to better understand and support participants experience of the course in its current, online format. To support learners, VentureWell deployed a new I-Corps video library centered on the Lean Startup method. Current I-Corps instructors were contracted to participate in the videos and provide content. All 34 videos in the new I-Corps video library have been successfully woven into the existing curriculum within the LMS platform. Over 5 cohorts, with 444 users and 54 instructors, have accessed and viewed these videos. This award also supported VentureWell in taking steps towards evaluation and data system optimization for the I-Corps program. As the program grows, it is critical that program outcomes, pedagogy, and follow-on results are continuously evaluated in order to monitor and maintain the quality and consistency of the program. This award significantly contributed to VentureWells ongoing efforts towards these goals. Last Modified: 04/17/2024 Submitted by: PhilipJWeilerstein
